values.title: Height scale when using png image as heightmap

content.raw:
I have been analysing how gazebo (v7.0) renders a `png` image when included as heightmap in a world file.

Assuming we have a `513x513 8bit png` where its maximum value is `127` and its minimum `0`. When I indicate the size of the collision/geometry element as `10 10 0.5`:

```
#!html

       <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <heightmap>
              <uri>model://worlds/steps.png</uri>
              <size>10 10 0.5</size>
              <pos>0 0 0</pos>
            </heightmap>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
```
*(Note: I indicate the same size in the visual/geometry/heightmap element of the world file)*

I expect the image to be rendered as a 10 x10m map with a maximum height value of  `0.5` meters. However it maximum height is around `0.25m`. Documentation mentions that the size either for collision or visual elements for a `heightmap` indicates the scale the heightmap to which it will be rendered in gazebo. It properly renders width and length but height seems unreliable. Am I missing something regarding how `Z` element in `size` is treated?

I have analysed other maps (same png size but different max/min values) and some times I get the height properly rendered, specially when the max value in the png is 255 and I want to render it to 1.0m.
content.html:
I have been analysing how gazebo (v7.0) renders a png image when included as heightmap in a world file.

Assuming we have a 513x513 8bit png where its maximum value is 127 and its minimum 0. When I indicate the size of the collision/geometry element as 10 10 0.5:

       <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <heightmap>
              <uri>model://worlds/steps.png</uri>
              <size>10 10 0.5</size>
              <pos>0 0 0</pos>
            </heightmap>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

(Note: I indicate the same size in the visual/geometry/heightmap element of the world file)

I expect the image to be rendered as a 10 x10m map with a maximum height value of 0.5 meters. However it maximum height is around 0.25m. Documentation mentions that the size either for collision or visual elements for a heightmap indicates the scale the heightmap to which it will be rendered in gazebo. It properly renders width and length but height seems unreliable. Am I missing something regarding how Z element in size is treated?

I have analysed other maps (same png size but different max/min values) and some times I get the height properly rendered, specially when the max value in the png is 255 and I want to render it to 1.0m.

values.title: texture scaling on heightmaps does not appear to be accurate

content.raw:
I created a height map and texture from ground truth data. They were validated as accurately aligned in qgis and similarly scaled. However when I rendered it in gazebo I had to adjust the texture size argument to 6000m from 7700m to render correctly. This number was determined by measuring the scaling difference between features in the rendering. 

First measuring the width. (also note that the depth and texture are both rendered and nicely aligned)

![half_true_width.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2525364132-half_true_width.png)

The original render

              <texture>
                <diffuse>file://media/textures/yosemite_color.png</diffuse>
                <normal>file://media/materials/textures/flat_normal.png</normal>
                <size>7700</size>
              </texture>

![half_accurate_width_bad_rendering.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3075180811-half_accurate_width_bad_rendering.png)

Measuring the offset
![half_measured_width_to_scale_texture.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2465943214-half_measured_width_to_scale_texture.png)

Rerendered with 

              <texture>
                <diffuse>file://media/textures/yosemite_color.png</diffuse>
                <normal>file://media/materials/textures/flat_normal.png</normal>
                <size>6000</size>
              </texture>

![half_scaled_down_accurate_rendering.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3220111716-half_scaled_down_accurate_rendering.png)

For testing this world is available here: https://github.com/osrf/uav_testing/tree/master/yosemite_valley
content.html:
I created a height map and texture from ground truth data. They were validated as accurately aligned in qgis and similarly scaled. However when I rendered it in gazebo I had to adjust the texture size argument to 6000m from 7700m to render correctly. This number was determined by measuring the scaling difference between features in the rendering.

First measuring the width. (also note that the depth and texture are both rendered and nicely aligned)

The original render

          <texture>
            <diffuse>file://media/textures/yosemite_color.png</diffuse>
            <normal>file://media/materials/textures/flat_normal.png</normal>
            <size>7700</size>
          </texture>

Measuring the offset

Rerendered with 

          <texture>
            <diffuse>file://media/textures/yosemite_color.png</diffuse>
            <normal>file://media/materials/textures/flat_normal.png</normal>
            <size>6000</size>
          </texture>

For testing this world is available here: https://github.com/osrf/uav_testing/tree/master/yosemite_valley

values.title: the default caching behavior of caching heightmaps and textures is not documented, indicated, or overridable

content.raw:
I was generating textured height maps and was having a really hard time debugging them since it seemed that anything I did didn't fix the rendering issue. Then I learned that the output was being cached. Which is why i would see intermittent changes but only if I changed the object name. 

It would be great to see:
 - that it's documented that caching is the default behavior. It's not mentioned in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=dem
- It would be good to print something in at least the verbose console output that this is happening
- It would be great to have an option to turn off the caching

As a workaround I've been running 

`rm -rf ~/.gazebo/paging/MODELNAME  && gazebo ...` when testing.
content.html:

It's not mentioned in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=dem - It would be good to print something in at least the verbose console output that this is happening - It would be great to have an option to turn off the caching

As a workaround I've been running

rm -rf ~/.gazebo/paging/MODELNAME && gazebo ... when testing.

values.title: Kinematic loops in dart not working with dart 6.7

content.html:
Since the release of dart 6.7, which included a refactor of the ConstraintSolver, our jenkins builds have shown two test failures of INTEGRATION_kinematic_loop for the dart test variant and compiler warnings complaining about use of deprecated syntax in DARTPhysics.cc.

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/385/testReport/
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/385/warnings22Result/

I've tried the following to update the syntax based on an example in the refactoring pull request, which fixes the deprecation warnings but not the test failure. Opening the test/worlds/anchored_loop.world shows that the loop is not connected.

diff -r 2584fc852e5d gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc        Mon Mar 11 00:59:07 2019 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc        Mon Mar 11 01:09:06 2019 -0700
@@ -591,15 +591,17 @@

   if (_type == "dantzig")
   {
-    this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getConstraintSolver()->setLCPSolver(
-        dart::common::make_unique<dart::constraint::DantzigLCPSolver>(
-        this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getTimeStep()));
+    this->dataPtr->dtWorld->setConstraintSolver(
+        dart::common::make_unique<dart::constraint::BoxedLcpConstraintSolver>(
+        this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getTimeStep(),
+        std::make_shared<dart::constraint::DantzigBoxedLcpSolver>()));
   }
   else if (_type == "pgs")
   {
-    this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getConstraintSolver()->setLCPSolver(
-        dart::common::make_unique<dart::constraint::PGSLCPSolver>(
-        this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getTimeStep()));
+    this->dataPtr->dtWorld->setConstraintSolver(
+        dart::common::make_unique<dart::constraint::BoxedLcpConstraintSolver>(
+        this->dataPtr->dtWorld->getTimeStep(),
+        std::make_shared<dart::constraint::PgsBoxedLcpSolver>()));
   }
   else
   {

Any advice from @jlee02 or @mxgrey would be appreciated.

values.title: Kinematic loop in anchored_world.world fails with dantzig LCP solver in DART

content.raw:
The kinematic loop in [test/worlds/anchored_loop.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0cc79a2e3c176cfd3bdf5437918c502eb0c5c59c/test/worlds/anchored_loop.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) fails to solve correctly with the dantzig LCP solver in DART. This was noted in the description of pull request #2756 when the test world was added, and was also noticed during the review of pull request #3086:

* #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3086/fix-2605-kinematic-loops-for-dart-67-and/diff#comment-96097536

There is a similar issue reported upstream at dartsim but for a different model that has contact between links instead of a closed kinematic loop:

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892

cc @jlee02
content.html:
The kinematic loop in test/worlds/anchored_loop.world fails to solve correctly with the dantzig LCP solver in DART. This was noted in the description of pull request #2756 when the test world was added, and was also noticed during the review of pull request #3086:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3086/fix-2605-kinematic-loops-for-dart-67-and/diff#comment-96097536

There is a similar issue reported upstream at dartsim but for a different model that has contact between links instead of a closed kinematic loop:

  • https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892

cc @jlee02

values.title: Invisible .dae

content.raw:
Hi,

I have transferred a Franka Emika Panda robot model from ROS Kinetic + Gazebo 7 to ROS Melodic + Gazebo 9. When I spawn the model in Gazebo 9 I can see the inertia and collision when I enable them from the View setting. Nevertheless, visual meshes (.dae) seems to be invisible.

Is this a possible bug or is there a way to update the .dae files such that Gazebo 9 can display the mesh?

Thanks
content.html:
Hi,

I have transferred a Franka Emika Panda robot model from ROS Kinetic + Gazebo 7 to ROS Melodic + Gazebo 9. When I spawn the model in Gazebo 9 I can see the inertia and collision when I enable them from the View setting. Nevertheless, visual meshes (.dae) seems to be invisible.

Is this a possible bug or is there a way to update the .dae files such that Gazebo 9 can display the mesh?

Thanks

values.title: ctest/nmake fail to run the tests on Windows

content.raw:
There is a problem when running tests on Windows using ctest or nmake. The error displayed by Jenkins (also present locally) is:

```
Test project D:/Jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/ws/gazebo/build
    Start 65: UNIT_Timer_TEST
1/2 Test #65: UNIT_Timer_TEST ..................***Exception: Exit code 0xc0000135
  0.00 sec
```

I think that the exception 0xc0000135 refers to the lack of a DLL to run the app. If the same test is called directly using the full path the test is executed fine. My main hypothesis is that somehow the PATH is not being respected (not the same) when running the tests through ctest.

We are using [cmake to include the PATH inside the tests](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0cc79a2e3c176cfd3bdf5437918c502eb0c5c59c/cmake/GazeboTestUtils.cmake#lines-65). One of my tests was to [modify the release-tools script to add the PATH before configure gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/compare/gazebo_windows_run_tests_clean%0Ddefault#diff) with the hope of getting the right paths at configuring time but no luck.

The results of that [release-tools modification](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/compare/gazebo_windows_run_tests_clean%0Ddefault#diff) can be found here: 
https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2504/console#console-section-1

@seanyen-msft do you have any idea what could be wrong? //cc @scpeters
content.html:
There is a problem when running tests on Windows using ctest or nmake. The error displayed by Jenkins (also present locally) is:

Test project D:/Jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/ws/gazebo/build
    Start 65: UNIT_Timer_TEST
1/2 Test #65: UNIT_Timer_TEST ..................***Exception: Exit code 0xc0000135
  0.00 sec

I think that the exception 0xc0000135 refers to the lack of a DLL to run the app. If the same test is called directly using the full path the test is executed fine. My main hypothesis is that somehow the PATH is not being respected (not the same) when running the tests through ctest.

We are using cmake to include the PATH inside the tests. One of my tests was to modify the release-tools script to add the PATH before configure gazebo with the hope of getting the right paths at configuring time but no luck.

The results of that release-tools modification can be found here: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/2504/console#console-section-1

@seanyen-msft do you have any idea what could be wrong? //cc @scpeters

values.title: [Gazebo9][Windows] ModelDatabase::GetModelPath implementation is incomplete on Windows build.

content.html:
#!/osrf/gazebo/src/868ff36b8b09f95eb73ebcf4bcd8ca88298a81aa/gazebo/common/ModelDatabase.cc#lines-506

I noticed that the GetModelPath requires libtar and maybe because of the lack of libtar port on Windows, some code path is disabled on Windows build, which breaks the scenario to use online models.

I'd like to use this bug to track how we should address this for Windows build.

values.title: Projector trespass objects

content.raw:
I would like to use projector on my project, for project a line to be used by a structured light algorithm. 

However I realized that the lines are projected also behind the objects, when objects were supposed to block the projection.

I looked to the current issues and haven't see any issue directly related to it. I was wondering if this is related to: #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2083/point-and-spot-lights-dont-cast-shadows or https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/issues/32/ogre1x-point-and-spot-lights-dont-cast

If so, is there any current alternative to it?

I'm running on Ubuntu 16.04 , Gazebo 9.8 and ign-rendering 0.29.1

values.title: Attach a joint between models in world plugin

content.raw:
Hi, I would like to attach a joint between models in world plugin
I follow the tutorial in [World plugins](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=plugins_world).
I can add the model to the world, however, I want to attach a joint between models like this
```
    sphereSDF.SetFromString(
       "<sdf version ='1.4'>\
          <model name ='sphere'>\
        <include>\
            <uri>model://payload</uri>\
            <pose>0.0 0.0 0.35 0 -1.57 0</pose>\
           </include>\
        <joint name='payload_link_drone_joint' type='fixed'>\
          <parent>iris::base_link</parent>\
          <child>unique_sphere::payload::payload_link</child>\
          <pose>-0.00 0.0 -0.25 0 0.0 0.0</pose>\
        </joint>\
          </model>\
        </sdf>");
        sdf::ElementPtr model = sphereSDF.Root()->GetElement("model");
         model->GetAttribute("name")->SetFromString("unique_sphere");
         this->world->InsertModelSDF(sphereSDF);
```
But the joint doesn't appear, is there any problem with my code?

        sdf::ElementPtr model = sphereSDF.Root()->GetElement("model");

values.title: Camera RGB to Bayer inverted

content.raw:
Hello, 

Converting Bayer images generated by Gazebo camera to RGB using OpenCV gives me inverted colors as the ones I expected. 

In my particular case I’m using BAYER\_GRBG8, but I only get the correct value when I convert from GBRG to RGB on OpenCV.

Looking the Camera.cc [source code](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/rendering/Camera.cc#lines-1299) one thing caught my attention. The indexes used to represent RGB are mapped as following:

`R = 2, G =1, B = 0`

Is that supposed to be like this? Or it is possible that gazebo is swapping Red and Blue colors when converting to Bayer?

PS: it also looks like the comments on the code mislead to the wrong interpretation, since `j` in my opinion refers to rows and not cols as it is written.

If this issue confirmed, I’d gladly open a PR to fix this.
content.html:
Hello,

Converting Bayer images generated by Gazebo camera to RGB using OpenCV gives me inverted colors as the ones I expected.

In my particular case I’m using BAYER_GRBG8, but I only get the correct value when I convert from GBRG to RGB on OpenCV.

Looking the Camera.cc source code one thing caught my attention. The indexes used to represent RGB are mapped as following:

R = 2, G =1, B = 0

Is that supposed to be like this? Or it is possible that gazebo is swapping Red and Blue colors when converting to Bayer?

PS: it also looks like the comments on the code mislead to the wrong interpretation, since j in my opinion refers to rows and not cols as it is written.

If this issue confirmed, I’d gladly open a PR to fix this.

values.title: physics::Model::RemoveChild() removes a wrong joint

content.raw:
physics::Model::RemoveChild\(\) can remove a wrong joint because it compares unscoped names at here\( [#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Model.cc#lines-392](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Model.cc#lines-392) \).

‌

When RemoveChild\(\) is requested to remove a link, it tries to remove the link and also joints whose parent or child is the link.  The issue is that it only compares unscoped names of parent and child links when searching the joints.   This search can pick wrong joints if the model has links whose unscoped names are same \(ex. “link“ and “nested\_model::link“\).  To fix this bug, I think GetName\(\) should be replaced to GetScopedName\(\) in the if-statement on the above URL.
content.html:
physics::Model::RemoveChild() can remove a wrong joint because it compares unscoped names at here( #!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Model.cc#lines-392 ).

‌

When RemoveChild() is requested to remove a link, it tries to remove the link and also joints whose parent or child is the link. The issue is that it only compares unscoped names of parent and child links when searching the joints. This search can pick wrong joints if the model has links whose unscoped names are same (ex. “link“ and “nested_model::link“). To fix this bug, I think GetName() should be replaced to GetScopedName() in the if-statement on the above URL.

values.title: physics::Link::Fini() leaves zombie update functions in sdf

content.raw:
Some member functions of physics::Link set update functions for the link’s sdf \(ex. [#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default#lines-159](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default#lines-159) \).    And these update functions remains after the link has been removed by physics::Model::RemoveChild\(\) or others.   If these zombie update functions are called by Update\(\) of a parent model’s sdf or others, a runtime error or segmentation fault occur.

In my opinion, physics::Link::Fini\(\) should make the final call of Update\(\) to write link’s final states to the sdf, and then detach update functions from the sdf.

Finally, this is an issue not only for physics::Link, but also for all classes which set update functions \(as of now, Battery, Inertial, Link and Model\).
content.html:
Some member functions of physics::Link set update functions for the link’s sdf (ex. #!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default#lines-159 ). And these update functions remains after the link has been removed by physics::Model::RemoveChild() or others. If these zombie update functions are called by Update() of a parent model’s sdf or others, a runtime error or segmentation fault occur.

In my opinion, physics::Link::Fini() should make the final call of Update() to write link’s final states to the sdf, and then detach update functions from the sdf.

Finally, this is an issue not only for physics::Link, but also for all classes which set update functions (as of now, Battery, Inertial, Link and Model).

values.title: physics::ODEJoint::LinkForce() can raise a segmentation fault by reading a null feedback pointer

content.raw:
The following joint feedback pointer in physics::ODEJoint::LinkForce\(\) \(or GetLinkForce\(\) in older versions\) can be null if <provide\_feedback> for the joint is false.  The current implementation raise a segfault on that case.  Please confirm the feedback pointer is not null like ODEJoint::LinkTorque\(\).

[#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc#lines-337](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c2936c66a23e6c6707fe4c7790458e75824407e/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc#lines-337)
content.html:
The following joint feedback pointer in physics::ODEJoint::LinkForce() (or GetLinkForce() in older versions) can be null if <provide_feedback> for the joint is false. The current implementation raise a segfault on that case. Please confirm the feedback pointer is not null like ODEJoint::LinkTorque().

values.title: gz topic -e exits when it encounters a NaN value

content.raw:
I was surprised to have it exit and not just print a warning or something else. It’s able to receive the message and count the frequency with gz topic -z I also know that the nan content was successfully propogating through the messages and into the other gazebo components that I verified by printf. And this could include 1 of 3 fields in a vector being nan and propagating that through the message.

‌

I was trying to debug a nan value originating from inside a gazebo plugin but I couldn’t debug using the usual tools as they just exited. Once I figured out that it was a nan value when it exited that got me most of what I needed in this case, but it’s suprising to have it exit instead of printing a place holder or a warning. 

‌

I validated this on both Gazebo 7 and Gazebo 9 running kinetic and melodic. Below is an animation you can see that I’m not pressing ^C to end the echo command. 

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/828536959-gz_topic_nan_quit.gif)

values.title: OpenGL deprecated in macOS 10.14

content.raw:
Gazebo uses ogre 1.9 with the OpenGL render engine, but the OpenGL framework has been deprecated in macOS 10.14, with the intention of driving users to use Metal. When OpenGL is removed, current versions of gazebo rendering won't work, and it probably won't compile since that is a required component.

* https://developer.apple.com/macos/whats-new/#deprecationofopenglandopencl

Ogre 2.1 supports Metal, and we have recently added support for ogre2.1 to ignition-rendering, so we should look into porting osrf/gazebo to use ogre2.1 with metal.

* https://www.ogre3d.org/about/what-version-to-choose

Prompted by this question on gazebo answers:

* http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/22570/what-is-the-future-of-gazebo-on-a-sans-opengl-macos/
content.html:
Gazebo uses ogre 1.9 with the OpenGL render engine, but the OpenGL framework has been deprecated in macOS 10.14, with the intention of driving users to use Metal. When OpenGL is removed, current versions of gazebo rendering won't work, and it probably won't compile since that is a required component.

  • https://developer.apple.com/macos/whats-new/#deprecationofopenglandopencl

Ogre 2.1 supports Metal, and we have recently added support for ogre2.1 to ignition-rendering, so we should look into porting osrf/gazebo to use ogre2.1 with metal.

  • https://www.ogre3d.org/about/what-version-to-choose

Prompted by this question on gazebo answers:

  • http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/22570/what-is-the-future-of-gazebo-on-a-sans-opengl-macos/

set (CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX /usr CACHE STRING "Install Prefix")

values.title: physics::Road Load function does not load the road properly from SDF.

content.html:
I’m trying to implement a simple Gazebo plugin that adapts the elevation of the roads extracted with OSM to the DEM file of the same region. For this purpose, I attended to accumulate all the roads in a world file as physics::RoadPtr objects. World class still lacks a proper support for the Road objects, therefore I came out with a workaround that uses Base and SDF objects to load the correct road portions. Below is an example code:

physics::BasePtr road_base = world->BaseByName(road_name);
physics::RoadPtr road(new physics::Road(road_base));
sdf::ElementPtr tmp = road_base->GetSDF();
road->Load(tmp);

I expect the road to be properly loaded. However when I execute road->Print("") to see whether it's filled, only the name of road is seen. Moreover, road->Points.size() gives 0 and road->GetWidth() outputs garbage values. Either Load function is not accurately implemented or I make a mistake at some point.

‌

When I looked to the source of Load function, I noticed that it uses Base->Load(sdf::ElementPtr). However, there is a problem in Base->Load at line 84. At the end it calls Base::RegisterIntrospectionItems(), which is empty. I think it’s deliberately left empty to be implemented in the future, however the physics::Road API does not work as expected due to this problem. This makes me wonder that any class inherits from Base should have a problem loading SDF portions, since the problem is at Base.

‌

EDIT: RegisterIntrospectionItems seems to be a protected function, which expects inheriting classes to implement itself. API specifies Link, Joint and Model classes implement it. Road also inherits from Base class, but does not implement it, which results in the current problem.

I’m open to any suggestion for a proper workaround other than editing the Gazebo source and having a source build, at least for the time being.

values.title: Gazebo Source Build Error

content.raw:
I am currently trying to build the latest release \(10.1\) from source. I have also installed the latest release sdformat and ignition packages from source.

‌

When trying to build gazebo dependencies \(sdformat and ignition packages\) from source, I follow this page \([http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install\_dependencies\_from\_source&cat=install](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_dependencies_from_source&cat=install)\) There is a versions section that lists the relevant sdformat/ignition versions to install for each Gazebo version. However, there is not an entry for the latest Gazebo release.

‌

Noting this I went ahead and just installed the latest releases for the sdformat/ignition packages dependencies. Going through the installation procedure I reach the following error:

```
-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
-- 	Missing: SDF version >=6. Required for reading and writing SDF files.
-- 	Missing: Ignition msgs1 library (libignition-msgs-dev).
-- 	Missing: Ignition math (libignition-math4-dev)
-- 	Missing: Ignition Transport (libignition-transport4-dev)
-- END BUILD ERRORS
```

Okay so this tells me the information that should probably be on the versions page, I linked earlier. So I realize I need to downgrade my ignition-msgs, math, transport, but my sdformat package is 8.2 which is >=6. Should this be changed to `=6` instead?

TLDR:

Installation documentation for dependent packages of gazebo is outdated \([http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install\_dependencies\_from\_source&cat=install](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_dependencies_from_source&cat=install)\)

And, sdformat version checking is incorrectly listed in gazebo’s CMakeLists.txt or gazebo is not properly finding sdformat 8.2 even when it is supposedly works.
content.html:
I am currently trying to build the latest release (10.1) from source. I have also installed the latest release sdformat and ignition packages from source.

‌

When trying to build gazebo dependencies (sdformat and ignition packages) from source, I follow this page (http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_dependencies_from_source&cat=install) There is a versions section that lists the relevant sdformat/ignition versions to install for each Gazebo version. However, there is not an entry for the latest Gazebo release.

‌

Noting this I went ahead and just installed the latest releases for the sdformat/ignition packages dependencies. Going through the installation procedure I reach the following error:

-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--  Missing: SDF version >=6. Required for reading and writing SDF files.
--  Missing: Ignition msgs1 library (libignition-msgs-dev).
--  Missing: Ignition math (libignition-math4-dev)
--  Missing: Ignition Transport (libignition-transport4-dev)
-- END BUILD ERRORS

Okay so this tells me the information that should probably be on the versions page, I linked earlier. So I realize I need to downgrade my ignition-msgs, math, transport, but my sdformat package is 8.2 which is >=6. Should this be changed to =6 instead?

TLDR:

Installation documentation for dependent packages of gazebo is outdated (http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_dependencies_from_source&cat=install)

And, sdformat version checking is incorrectly listed in gazebo’s CMakeLists.txt or gazebo is not properly finding sdformat 8.2 even when it is supposedly works.

content.raw:

How could I change the datatype in gazebo laserscaner

values.title: Collision checking with Ray doesn't work for boxes not aligned in the world

content.raw:
I've attached plugin code to demonstrate the issue, which to be honest I don't understand very well. Somehow I am getting incorrect, and inconsistently, results from checking `GetIntersection` on a ray. I've looked into the Gazebo code a bit, and from what I can tell it's not a data race with the physics engine because `GetIntersection` takes a lock, and it clearly has something to do with the aligned-ness of the object, since I can’t find any errors when the boxes axes are aligned with the world axes.

Here’s the code and world file to reproduce. You can test by stepping gazebo while putting the a basic 1m box in various positions. See the example image for a configuration that doesn't work \(the position need not be precise\).

[https://github.com/PeterMitrano/test\_ray\_plugin](https://github.com/PeterMitrano/test_ray_plugin)

Here’s the code and world file to reproduce. You can test by stepping gazebo while putting the a basic 1m box in various positions. See the example image for a configuration that doesn't work (the position need not be precise).

values.title: libgazebo9-dev unmet dependencies error (ubuntu 18.04)

content.raw:
Hello, I am trying to install gazebo9 on ubuntu 18.04 but I am facing some unmet dependencies errors. Initially I tried running the one-liner command `curl -sSL <http://get.gazebosim.org> | sh` but it threw the error,

```
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
libgazebo9-dev : Depends: libgazebo9 (= 9.10.0-1~bionic) but it is not going to be installed
                 Depends: gazebo9-plugin-base (= 9.10.0-1~bionic)
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
```

So I tried to manually install the dependencies `libgazebo9` and `gazebo9-plugin-base` with `sudo apt install` and it was successful. With both `libgazebo9 (version 9.10.0-1~bionic)` and `gazebo9-plugin-base (version 9.10.0-1~bionic)` **successfully** installed, I tried to install run the one-liner command again but it is still throwing the same error that the dependencies are not met when I have installed the dependencies already.

In order to confirm whether the dependencies are met, I also ran the command `apt-rdepends -p libgazebo9-dev`, and the output shows that both `libgazebo9 (version 9.10.0-1~bionic)` and `gazebo9-plugin-base (version 9.10.0-1~bionic)`are installed.

Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
libgazebo9-dev : Depends: libgazebo9 (= 9.10.0-1~bionic) but it is not going to be installed
                 Depends: gazebo9-plugin-base (= 9.10.0-1~bionic)
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.

So I tried to manually install the dependencies libgazebo9 and gazebo9-plugin-base with sudo apt install and it was successful. With both libgazebo9 (version 9.10.0-1~bionic) and gazebo9-plugin-base (version 9.10.0-1~bionic) successfully installed, I tried to install run the one-liner command again but it is still throwing the same error that the dependencies are not met when I have installed the dependencies already.

In order to confirm whether the dependencies are met, I also ran the command apt-rdepends -p libgazebo9-dev, and the output shows that both libgazebo9 (version 9.10.0-1~bionic) and gazebo9-plugin-base (version 9.10.0-1~bionic)are installed.

values.title: Gazebo freezes on Save As with too many cameras

content.raw:
I have installed Gazebo 9 with ROS melodic on Ubuntu 18.04. I keep getting following unexpected behaviour:

Create a new world in Gazebo (only ground plane and sun)
Add an object to the world (any object e.g. a car)
Add cameras to the world (4 cameras needed, from standard library)
File -> Save As... or Ctrl+Shift+S
The program freezes and the saving window does not show up
gzclient process starts using 100% CPU
It is possible to Alt+F4 to return to the world editor. The only thing showing up in the terminal: 
*Gtk-Message: 16:30:04.390: GtkDialog mapped without a transient parent. This is discouraged.*
content.html:
I have installed Gazebo 9 with ROS melodic on Ubuntu 18.04. I keep getting following unexpected behaviour:

Create a new world in Gazebo (only ground plane and sun) Add an object to the world (any object e.g. a car) Add cameras to the world (4 cameras needed, from standard library) File -> Save As... or Ctrl+Shift+S The program freezes and the saving window does not show up gzclient process starts using 100% CPU It is possible to Alt+F4 to return to the world editor. The only thing showing up in the terminal: Gtk-Message: 16:30:04.390: GtkDialog mapped without a transient parent. This is discouraged.

values.title: audio simulation
<static> tag is not enforced when there are more than <gazebo> tags in a robot description

content.raw:
When you have a static model, if there are more than one <gazebo> tags in the description, the `<static>true</static>` snippet has to appear in all of them for the property to be enforced. Otherwise, the model is rendered as non-static, while the following warning is thrown:

```
Warning [parser_urdf.cc:1119] multiple inconsistent <static> exists due to fixed joint reduction overwriting previous value [true] with [false].
```

I’m using gazebo 9.10 and here is a minimal example to reproduce this:

```
<robot name="robot" xmlns:xacro="http://ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="base_footprint" />
  <joint name="base_footprint_to_base_link" type="fixed">
    <origin xyz="0 0 0.5" rpy="0 0 0" />
    <parent link="base_footprint" />
    <child link="base_link" />
  </joint>
  <link name="base_link">    
    <inertial>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <mass value="0.001" />
      <inertia ixx="0.001" ixy="0.0" ixz="0.0" iyy="0.001" iyz="0.0" izz="0.001" />
    </inertial>
    <visual>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <geometry>
        <box size="1 1 1" />
      </geometry>
    </visual>
    <collision>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <geometry>
        <box size="1 1 1" />
      </geometry>
    </collision>
  </link>

  <gazebo>
    <static>true</static>
  </gazebo>

  <gazebo>
    <plugin name="gazebo_ros_control" filename="libgazebo_ros_control.so">
      <robotSimType>gazebo_ros_control/DefaultRobotHWSim</robotSimType>
      <legacyModeNS>false</legacyModeNS>
    </plugin>
  </gazebo>
</robot>
```
content.html:
When you have a static model, if there are more than one <gazebo> tags in the description, the <static>true</static> snippet has to appear in all of them for the property to be enforced. Otherwise, the model is rendered as non-static, while the following warning is thrown:

Warning [parser_urdf.cc:1119] multiple inconsistent <static> exists due to fixed joint reduction overwriting previous value [true] with [false].

I’m using gazebo 9.10 and here is a minimal example to reproduce this:

<robot name="robot" xmlns:xacro="http://ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="base_footprint" />
  <joint name="base_footprint_to_base_link" type="fixed">
    <origin xyz="0 0 0.5" rpy="0 0 0" />
    <parent link="base_footprint" />
    <child link="base_link" />
  </joint>
  <link name="base_link">    
    <inertial>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <mass value="0.001" />
      <inertia ixx="0.001" ixy="0.0" ixz="0.0" iyy="0.001" iyz="0.0" izz="0.001" />
    </inertial>
    <visual>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <geometry>
        <box size="1 1 1" />
      </geometry>
    </visual>
    <collision>
      <origin xyz="0 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <geometry>
        <box size="1 1 1" />
      </geometry>
    </collision>
  </link>

  <gazebo>
    <static>true</static>
  </gazebo>

  <gazebo>
    <plugin name="gazebo_ros_control" filename="libgazebo_ros_control.so">
      <robotSimType>gazebo_ros_control/DefaultRobotHWSim</robotSimType>
      <legacyModeNS>false</legacyModeNS>
    </plugin>
  </gazebo>
</robot>

values.title: Camera sensor set to orthographic projection gives an empty image.

content.raw:
Setting a camera sensor’s “projection\_type” element to “orthographic” gives me an empty image but otherwise seems to work fine \(no errors or crashing\). Explicitly setting to “persepective” works as expected.

‌

Also, this element is not documented in the SDFormat spec on the website. Is this just not implemented? On a surface glance, it seems to be there, setting the projection in the ogre camera.
content.html:
Setting a camera sensor’s “projection_type” element to “orthographic” gives me an empty image but otherwise seems to work fine (no errors or crashing). Explicitly setting to “persepective” works as expected.

‌

Also, this element is not documented in the SDFormat spec on the website. Is this just not implemented? On a surface glance, it seems to be there, setting the projection in the ogre camera.

values.title: Projector not visible on meshes

content.raw:
Hello,

I have an issue with the projector. I'm trying to project a laser line into the scene, similar to [here](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/16441/simulating-a-structured-light-sensor-in-gazebo/). However, there is no projected image if it is projected on a model with a mesh. Basic geometries are working. The image below shows this. The projected image is visible on the box, but not on the sea-bed. The seabed comes from [here](https://github.com/uuvsimulator/uuv_simulator/blob/master/uuv_gazebo_worlds/models/sand_heightmap/model.sdf). I have tested it with Gazebo 7 and 9. Am I doing something wrong or is it a bug?
![projector_issue](https://i.ibb.co/ZcBPWSZ/projector-issue.png)
content.html:
Hello,

I have an issue with the projector. I'm trying to project a laser line into the scene, similar to here. However, there is no projected image if it is projected on a model with a mesh. Basic geometries are working. The image below shows this. The projected image is visible on the box, but not on the sea-bed. The seabed comes from here. I have tested it with Gazebo 7 and 9. Am I doing something wrong or is it a bug?

values.title: StaticMapPlugin: boost::filesystem::rename: Invalid cross-device link: "/tmp/<model_name>", "/home/.../.gazebo/models/<model_name>"

content.raw:
If the temporary path (`/tmp`) is in a different source system, `boost::filesystem::rename` fails with the error on the title. I think it is required a try catch around #!/osrf/gazebo/src/cf248d4ed5e629318f1ba68aa98ba498b52ed3dc/plugins/StaticMapPlugin.cc#lines-411 that verifies if the rename is possible, and if not, just copy and replace it in the `~/gazebo` folder.
This basically is making the plugin unusable in my case.
content.html: If the temporary path (/tmp) is in a different source system, boost::filesystem::rename fails with the error on the title. I think it is required a try catch around #!/osrf/gazebo/src/cf248d4ed5e629318f1ba68aa98ba498b52ed3dc/plugins/StaticMapPlugin.cc#lines-411 that verifies if the rename is possible, and if not, just copy and replace it in the ~/gazebo folder. This basically is making the plugin unusable in my case.

values.title: Laser scan ray goes through walls when using heightmaps

content.raw:
Hi,

I am trying to use heightmaps for random map generation that I plan to use for testing the Navigation 2 stack.

I am able to generate heightmaps, but I am having a problem when using a laser sensor. The laser scan rays go through the model. You can see the problem in the images as well.

I have attached the model files (heightmap model and the turtlebot 3 robot model) that can be used to reproduce this issue. I was wondering if this is a Gazebo bug or I set some parameters wrong in my .sdf file.

(In the images, I increased the laser scan range to show the problem)


Ubuntu 18.04.03
Gazebo 9.11.0
Grayscale image resolution: 513x513

I posted this here as well. http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/23806/laser-scan-ray-goes-through-walls-when-using-heightmaps/
Thanks,
Melih

values.title: PX4 SITL data rates

content.raw:
What are the normal date rates and their ranges in PX4 SITL using Gazebo at the following ports: Please see this diagram [https://dev.px4.io/master/en/simulation/ros\_interface.html](https://dev.px4.io/master/en/simulation/ros_interface.html)

1.  Simulator and PX4 on SITL ports: At TCP 4560 port.
2.  QGC and PX4 on SITL: UDP 14570 - UDP 14550 
3.  API/offboard : UDP 14580-UDP 14540.

‌

  1. Simulator and PX4 on SITL ports: At TCP 4560 port.
  2. QGC and PX4 on SITL: UDP 14570 - UDP 14550

values.title: Plugin for rotating velodyne around an axis passing through its center

content.html:
Hi,

I'm trying to create a plugin to make velodyne VLP-16 Lidar rotate around an axis passing through its center (X or Y axis). This generates 16 rotating scan lines subject to the effect of their natural rotation around the Z axis and another rotation of the velodyne body around X or Y axis.

I'm using gazebo 9.0 and ros Melodic.

The URDF joint definition is :

<joint name="${name}_base_mount_joint" type="continuous">
      <xacro:insert_block name="origin" />
      <parent link="${namespace}/${parent}"/>
      <child link="${namespace}/${name}"/>
      <!-- origin xyz="0 0 -0.11885" rpy="3.14 0 0" /-->
      <axis xyz="1 0 0" rpy="0 0 0" />
      <limit effort="100" velocity="1"/>
      <joint_properties damping="0.0" friction="0.0"/>
    </joint>

  <!-- Transmission is important to link the joints and the controller -->
    <transmission name="${name}_base_mount_joint_trans">
      <type>transmission_interface/SimpleTransmission</type>
      <joint name="${name}_base_mount_joint">
     <hardwareInterface>EffortJointInterface</hardwareInterface>
      </joint>
      <actuator name="${name}_base_mount_joint_motor">
    <hardwareInterface>EffortJointInterface</hardwareInterface>
        <mechanicalReduction>1</mechanicalReduction>
      </actuator>
    </transmission>

  <gazebo>
    <plugin name="gazebo_rotate_velodyne_plugin" filename="libgazebo_ros_rotate_velodyne.so">
      <alwaysOn>true</alwaysOn>
      <updateRate>100.0</updateRate>
      <velocity>50</velocity>
      <MotorJoint>velodyne_base_mount_joint</MotorJoint>
      <torque>60</torque>
      <broadcastTF>1</broadcastTF>
      <commandTopic>cmd_vel</commandTopic>
      <robotBaseFrame>base_link</robotBaseFrame>
    </plugin>
  </gazebo>

  The plugin configuration is this:

  #ifndef _VELODYNE_PLUGIN_HH_
#define _VELODYNE_PLUGIN_HH_    
#include <gazebo/gazebo.hh>
#include <gazebo/physics/physics.hh>
#include <ros/ros.h>
#include <geometry_msgs/Twist.h>
#include <nav_msgs/Odometry.h>
// Boost
#include <boost/thread.hpp>
// Custom Callback Queue
#include <ros/callback_queue.h>
#include <gazebo/physics/physics.hh>
#include "ros/callback_queue.h"
#include "ros/subscribe_options.h"
#include "std_msgs/Float32.h"
#include <gazebo/transport/transport.hh>
#include <gazebo/msgs/msgs.hh>

namespace gazebo
{
  /// \brief A plugin to control a Velodyne sensor.
  class GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin : public ModelPlugin
  {
    /// \brief Constructor
    public: GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin() {}
    /// \brief The load function is called by Gazebo when the plugin is
    /// inserted into simulation
    /// \param[in] _model A pointer to the model that this plugin is
    /// attached to.
    /// \param[in] _sdf A pointer to the plugin's SDF element.
    public: virtual void Load(physics::ModelPtr _model, sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
{
    // Output this message to see if this plugin is attached to our velodyne model
    std::cerr << "\nThe velodyne plugin is attach to model[" <<
              _model->GetName() << "]\n";
  // Safety check
  if (_model->GetJointCount() == 0)
  {
    std::cerr << "Invalid joint count, Velodyne plugin not loaded\n";
    return;
  }
  // Store the model pointer for convenience.
  this->model = _model;
  // Get the first joint. We are making an assumption about the model
  // having one joint that is the rotational joint.
  this->joint = _model->GetJoints()[0];
  // Setup a P-controller, with a gain of 0.1.
  this->pid = common::PID(0.1, 0.1, 0.1);
  // Apply the P-controller to the joint.
  this->model->GetJointController()->SetVelocityPID(
      this->joint->GetScopedName(), this->pid);
  // Default to zero velocity
  this->velocity = 0;
  // Check that the velocity element exists, then read the value
  if (_sdf->HasElement("velocity"))
      velocity = _sdf->Get<double>("velocity");

  this->SetVelocity(velocity);

  // Create the node
  this->node = transport::NodePtr(new transport::Node());
    #if GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION < 8
              this->node->Init(this->model->GetWorld()->GetName());
    #else
              this->node->Init(this->model->GetWorld()->Name());
    #endif

  // Create a topic name
  std::string topicName = "~/" + this->model->GetName() + "/vel_cmd";

  // Subscribe to the topic, and register a callback
  this->sub = this->node->Subscribe(topicName,
                                    &GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin::OnMsg, this);

  this->torque = 50.0;
    if (!_sdf->HasElement("torque")) {
      ROS_WARN_NAMED("rotate_velodyne_plugin", "GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin Plugin (ns = %s) missing <torque>, defaults to %f",
          this->robot_namespace_.c_str(), this->torque);
    } else {
      this->torque = _sdf->GetElement("torque")->Get<double>();
    }

    this->command_topic_ = "cmd_vel";
    if (!_sdf->HasElement("commandTopic")) {
      ROS_WARN_NAMED("rotate_velodyne_plugin", "GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin Plugin (ns = %s) missing <commandTopic>, defaults to \"%s\"",
          this->robot_namespace_.c_str(), this->command_topic_.c_str());
    } else {
      this->command_topic_ = _sdf->GetElement("commandTopic")->Get<std::string>();
    }

    this->robot_base_frame_ = "base_link";
    if (!_sdf->HasElement("robotBaseFrame")) {
      ROS_WARN_NAMED("rotate_velodyne_plugin", "GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin Plugin (ns = %s) missing <robotBaseFrame>, defaults to \"%s\"",
          this->robot_namespace_.c_str(), this->robot_base_frame_.c_str());
    } else {
      this->robot_base_frame_ = _sdf->GetElement("robotBaseFrame")->Get<std::string>();
    }

    this->update_rate_ = 100.0;
    if (!_sdf->HasElement("updateRate")) {
      ROS_WARN_NAMED("rotate_velodyne_plugin", "GazeboRosRotateVelodynePlugin Plugin (ns = %s) missing <updateRate>, defaults to %f",
          this->robot_namespace_.c_str(), this->update_rate_);
    } else {
      this->update_rate_ = _sdf->GetElement("updateRate")->Get<double>();
    }
          // Initialize ros, if it has not already bee initialized.
          if (!ros::isInitialized())
          {
              int argc = 0;
              char **argv = NULL;
              ros::init(argc, argv, "gazebo_client",
                        ros::init_options::NoSigintHandler);
          }
// Create our ROS node. This acts in a similar manner to
// the Gazebo node
          this->rosNode.reset(new ros::NodeHandle("gazebo_client"));

          // Create a named topic, and subscribe to it.
          ros::SubscribeOptions so =
                  ros::SubscribeOptions::create<std_msgs::Float32>(
                          "/" + this->model->GetName() + "/vel_cmd",
                          1,
                          boost::bind(&GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin::OnRosMsg, this, _1),
                          ros::VoidPtr(), &this->rosQueue);
          this->rosSub = this->rosNode->subscribe(so);
// Spin up the queue helper thread.
          this->rosQueueThread =
                  std::thread(std::bind(&GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin::QueueThread, this));
}
       /// \brief Set the velocity of the Velodyne
      /// \param[in] _vel New target velocity
  public: void SetVelocity(const double &_vel)
      {
          // Set the joint's target velocity.
          this->model->GetJointController()->SetVelocityTarget(
                  this->joint->GetScopedName(), _vel);
      }
      /// \brief Handle incoming message
      /// \param[in] _msg Repurpose a vector3 message. This function will
      /// only use the x component.
  private: void OnMsg(ConstVector3dPtr &_msg)
      {
          this->SetVelocity(_msg->x());
      }
      /// \brief A node used for transport
  private: transport::NodePtr node;

      /// \brief A subscriber to a named topic.
  private: transport::SubscriberPtr sub;

      /// \brief Handle an incoming message from ROS
      /// \param[in] _msg A float value that is used to set the velocity
      /// of the Velodyne.
  public: void OnRosMsg(const std_msgs::Float32ConstPtr &_msg)
      {
          this->SetVelocity(_msg->data);
      }

      /// \brief ROS helper function that processes messages
  private: void QueueThread()
      {
          static const double timeout = 0.01;
          while (this->rosNode->ok())
          {
              this->rosQueue.callAvailable(ros::WallDuration(timeout));
          }
      }
    /// \brief Pointer to the model.
  private: physics::ModelPtr model;

    /// \brief Pointer to the joint.
  private: physics::JointPtr joint;

    /// \brief A PID controller for the joint.
  private: common::PID pid;

      /// \brief A node use for ROS transport
  private: std::unique_ptr<ros::NodeHandle> rosNode;

    /// \brief A ROS subscriber
  private: ros::Subscriber rosSub;

    /// \brief A ROS callbackqueue that helps process messages
  private: ros::CallbackQueue rosQueue;

    /// \brief A thread the keeps running the rosQueue
  private: std::thread rosQueueThread;

private:
      double update_rate_;
      double velocity;
      double torque;
      double x_;
      double rot_;
      std::string robot_namespace_;
      std::string command_topic_;
      std::string robot_base_frame_;
      boost::mutex lock;
      ros::CallbackQueue queue_;
      boost::thread callback_queue_thread_;
      ros::Subscriber cmd_vel_subscriber_;
      ros::NodeHandle* rosnode_;
  };
  // Tell Gazebo about this plugin, so that Gazebo can call Load on this plugin.
  GZ_REGISTER_MODEL_PLUGIN(GazeboRotateVelodynePlugin)
}
#endif

The problem is when I come to get rviz to publish the PointCloud2 message I get difformed data. All data are published on one single axis.

The second problem is that I can't control the rotating joint by the /cmd_vel topic, I send commmands using : rostopic pub /vel_cmd std_msgs/Float32 5.0 but nothing changes.

Anyone any idea where the problem lies please?

values.title: CMake 3.11 will stop supporting multiline cache strings

content.raw:
Gazebo uses multiline CMake cache strings in files like [#!/osrf/gazebo/src/13b71990d5449de589e4dcaa83dbc711394650ed/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt#lines-219](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/13b71990d5449de589e4dcaa83dbc711394650ed/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt#lines-219) .

CMake 3.11 will stop supporting this: [https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.15/release/3.11.html#other-changes](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.15/release/3.11.html#other-changes) .

Practically, it doesn’t seem to be a big problem, because if I understand it correctly, this cache string is actually never loaded from the cache as its only usage is being directly handed off to configure\_file. I verified it and the generated file [config.](http://config.gg)hh looks correct and contains many include lines.

This is what CMakeCache.txt looks like when built with CMake 3.15:

‌

```
//Common Headers
common_headers:INTERNAL= #include "gazebo/common/Animation.hh"
# WARNING: Value of common_headers contained a newline and was
#  truncated. Original value:
#  #include "gazebo/common/Animation.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Assert.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Battery.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Base64.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/BVHLoader.hh"
...
```

And these warnings are written to the console:

‌

```
CMake Warning:                                                                                      
  Value of common_headers contained a newline; truncating   
```

So, the question is: is it still needed to save these variables to cache?
content.html:
Gazebo uses multiline CMake cache strings in files like #!/osrf/gazebo/src/13b71990d5449de589e4dcaa83dbc711394650ed/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt#lines-219 .

CMake 3.11 will stop supporting this: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.15/release/3.11.html#other-changes .

Practically, it doesn’t seem to be a big problem, because if I understand it correctly, this cache string is actually never loaded from the cache as its only usage is being directly handed off to configure_file. I verified it and the generated file config.hh looks correct and contains many include lines.

This is what CMakeCache.txt looks like when built with CMake 3.15:

‌

//Common Headers
common_headers:INTERNAL= #include "gazebo/common/Animation.hh"
# WARNING: Value of common_headers contained a newline and was
#  truncated. Original value:
#  #include "gazebo/common/Animation.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Assert.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Battery.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/Base64.hh"
# \n #include "gazebo/common/BVHLoader.hh"
...

And these warnings are written to the console:

‌

CMake Warning:                                                                                      
  Value of common_headers contained a newline; truncating

So, the question is: is it still needed to save these variables to cache?

values.title: Pose tag gets ignored when using urdf

content.raw:
When creating a sensor in an urdf using the `<gazebo>` tag the any `<pose>` tag inside the `<sensor>` gets ignored. 

Here for example I'm trying to rotate a sensor 90° on the z-Axis. Inside the gazebo-simulation the orientation remains the same with or without the tag. 
```
#!xml

        <gazebo reference="lidar_link">
             <sensor type="ray" name="head_hokuyo_sensor">
                 <visualize>true</visualize>
                 <update_rate>10</update_rate>
                 <pose>0 0 0 0 0 1.570796</pose>
                 <ray>
                     <scan>
                         <horizontal>
                             <samples>100</samples>
                             <resolution>1</resolution>
                             <min_angle>-1.570796</min_angle>
                             <max_angle>1.570796</max_angle>
                         </horizontal>
                     </scan>
                     <range>
                         <min>0.10</min>
                         <max>30.0</max>
                         <resolution>0.01</resolution>
                     </range>
                     <noise>
                         <type>gaussian</type>
                         <mean>0.0</mean>
                         <stddev>0.01</stddev>
                     </noise>
                 </ray>
                 <plugin name="gazebo_ros_head_hokuyo_controller" filename="libgazebo_ros_
    laser.so">
                     <topicName>scan</topicName>
                     <frameName>lidar</frameName>
                 </plugin>
             </sensor>
          </gazebo>


```

values.title: SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin: multiple instances of plugin interfere with each other

content.raw:
If multiple vehicles using the SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin plugin are created, they interfere with each other because each instance of the plugin considers all track bodies \(not just those of the plugin instance’s model\) as tracks of the model.

I believe this is due to a lack of checking if the bodies of the contact joints that are used to move the vehicle are actually the tracks of this vehicle. The plugin does use category bits but uses the same category bits for all instances of the plugin.

I have fixed this in a branch here: [https://bitbucket.org/somniac/gazebo/branch/multiple\_tracked\_vehicle\_plugins#diff](https://bitbucket.org/somniac/gazebo/branch/multiple_tracked_vehicle_plugins#diff)
content.html:
If multiple vehicles using the SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin plugin are created, they interfere with each other because each instance of the plugin considers all track bodies (not just those of the plugin instance’s model) as tracks of the model.

I believe this is due to a lack of checking if the bodies of the contact joints that are used to move the vehicle are actually the tracks of this vehicle. The plugin does use category bits but uses the same category bits for all instances of the plugin.

I have fixed this in a branch here: https://bitbucket.org/somniac/gazebo/branch/multiple_tracked_vehicle_plugins#diff

I’m using many custom Gazebo and ROS plugins, but none interfere with lights and the scene I’m loading also has lights untouched compared to empty.world. I’m on Gazebo 9.11.0 installed from OSRF PPA on Ubuntu 18.04.

‌

OGRE EXCEPTION(4:ItemIdentityException): An object of type 'Light' with name 'sun' already exists. in SceneManager::createMovableObject at /build/ogre-1.9-B6QkmW/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/src/OgreSceneManager.cpp (line 6832)\nUnable to create a light\n"

values.title: SonarSensor_TEST.CreateSonar failures with dart

content.raw:
The `SonarSensor_TEST.CreateSonar` test cases in `UNIT_SonarSensor_TEST` occasionally fail for dart during teardown. I've uploaded a backtrace to the following gist:

* https://gist.github.com/scpeters/09b10d03952af8adbffe47bd2632abea

Here is the console output:

~~~
[ RUN      ] SonarTests/SonarSensor_TEST.CreateSonar/7
[Dbg] [SonarSensor_TEST.cc:195] Physics dart paused 1
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.90
[Dbg] [DARTModel.cc:72] Initializing DART model ground_plane
[Dbg] [DARTModel.cc:128] Building DART BodyNode for link 'link' with a free joint.
Warning [BodyNode.cpp:498] [BodyNode] A negative or zero mass [0] is set to BodyNode [link], which can cause invalid physical behavior or segfault. Consider setting positive value instead.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:209] ServerFixture load in 0.7 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
Warning [parser.cc:540] Converting a deprecated SDF source[data-string].
[Err] [Publisher.cc:101] Publishing an uninitialized message on topic[/gazebo/default/ground_plane/link/sonar/sonar]. Required field [sonar.geometry] missing.
[Err] [Publisher.cc:101] Publishing an uninitialized message on topic[/gazebo/default/ground_plane/link/sonar/sonar]. Required field [sonar.geometry] missing.
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:135] ServerFixture::Unload
Warning [World.cpp:355] [World::removeSkeleton] Skeleton [ground_plane] is not in the world.
~~~

Here is an excerpt of the backtrace showing a dart failure in the `~SonarSensor` destructor.

~~~
#0  0x00007f7c06594574 in  () at /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdart.so.6.10
#1  0x00007f7c06594bca in dart::dynamics::JacobianNode::~JacobianNode() () at /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdart.so.6.10

values.title: IMU sensor noise isn't properly scaled?

content.raw:
I’ve just looked in the source code of the IMU sensor. It seems to me that the sensor noise isn’t properly scaled by `dt` in the update method. That seems pretty wrong, doesn’t it?

If the user is expected to enter the noise values scaled by sensor update rate, it should be mentioned somewhere. But the [tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=sensor_noise&cat=sensors#IMUnoise) says the units are rad/s or m/s^2.
content.html:
I’ve just looked in the source code of the IMU sensor. It seems to me that the sensor noise isn’t properly scaled by dt in the update method. That seems pretty wrong, doesn’t it?

If the user is expected to enter the noise values scaled by sensor update rate, it should be mentioned somewhere. But the tutorial says the units are rad/s or m/s^2.

values.title: Gazebo10 for Ubuntu 19.10 (Pop OS) "no release file found"

content.raw:
Hi, I just tried to install Gazebo 10 with the shell script from the website on my Pop OS 19.10 VM and it did run the script but when I try to start gazebo with "gazebo" in the terminal, it tells me it's not installed and I should get it with apt install. However, this only supports gazebo9. When I scrolled up the terminal output, I saw an error about not finding a release file for "eoan" (so the 19.10 version) and that this is not secure, so it wouldn't be installed or something. then it proceeded to get the dependencies of course and told me it's finished. I assume there is just not a release build for Ubuntu 19.10 in the repo yet? When is this going to be added because I would like to install Pop OS 19.10 on my new laptop in about 2 weeks.

Thanks for the help in advance!

values.title: contact normal changes randomly between two opposite directions

content.raw:
hello,

I found this bug when attaching a contact sensor to a model, with DART physics engine and Gazebo 9.

When I display the gazebo topic associated with this sensor, I can see that the normals of the contacts are not constant, even if the model is lying on the ground and is at rest \(only gravity force is applied on it\). More precisely, the directions of the normals oscillate between approximately \(0, 0, 1\), and \(-0, -0, -1\). The sign of the associated force also vary accordingly.

The bug is very easy to reproduce, you just need to attach a contact sensor to a model, and display the associated gazebo topic.

This is a blocker for my application, so any help is appreciated! Do someone know in which class/function I should look to find this bug ? I think it may be in [RetrieveDARTCollisions](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/adb8676f9c91f76421b6a04ca9439bc8200ee047/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc#lines-236), because a lot of contacts related things are made here, even if I don’t see anything about the contact normal…

‌

More precisely, the directions of the normals oscillate between approximately (0, 0, 1), and (-0, -0, -1). The sign of the associated force also vary accordingly.

The bug is very easy to reproduce, you just need to attach a contact sensor to a model, and display the associated gazebo topic.

values.title: max_contacts sdf parameter is not working with dart

content.raw:
hello,

the sdf parameter <max\_contacts>, which is supposed to set the maximum number of contacts between two colliding body, is not working with dart engine \(it is working correctly with ode\)

To reproduce the bug, set this parameter on a model with a contact sensor, and display the contact topic.
content.html:
hello,

the sdf parameter <max_contacts>, which is supposed to set the maximum number of contacts between two colliding body, is not working with dart engine (it is working correctly with ode)

To reproduce the bug, set this parameter on a model with a contact sensor, and display the contact topic.

values.title: Some issues on arm-based system

content.raw:
Hello there, 

I was trying to install gazebo9 on my IPC with Nvidia jetson-xavier CPU. Yet, there are several issues thwarting my way. 

1\. The debian versions of gazebo9 and its dependencies do not match.  gazebo9-common’s version is 9.11, which does not support to gazebo9 9.8.0.   In order to get things done, eventually I chose to install 9.0.0 version, and it worked just fine.

```
gazebo9:
  Installed: (none)
  Candidate: 9.8.0-1~bionic
  Version table:
     9.8.0-1~bionic 500
        500 http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu-stable bionic/main arm64 Packages
     9.0.0+dfsg5-3ubuntu1+ppa2 500
        500 http://packages.ros.org/ros/ubuntu bionic/main arm64 Packages
        500 http://packages.ros.org/ros2/ubuntu bionic/main arm64 Packages
     9.0.0+dfsg5-3ubuntu1 500
        500 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports bionic/universe arm64 Packages
        
gazebo9-common:
  Installed: (none)
  Candidate: 9.11.0-1~bionic
  Version table:
     9.11.0-1~bionic 500
        500 http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu-stable bionic/main arm64 Packages
     9.0.0+dfsg5-3ubuntu1+ppa2 500
        500 http://packages.ros.org/ros/ubuntu bionic/main arm64 Packages
        500 http://packages.ros.org/ros2/ubuntu bionic/main amd64 Packages
        500 http://packages.ros.org/ros2/ubuntu bionic/main arm64 Packages
     9.0.0+dfsg5-3ubuntu1 500
        500 http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports bionic/universe arm64 Packages
```

‌

2\.  There’s an issue in symbolic links \( I’m not sure if it is caused by gazebo \), which had been answered by Nvidia Developer Forums [here](https://devtalk.nvidia.com/default/topic/1042381/jetson-agx-xavier/problem-with-gazebo-/1).

```shell
 sudo rm /usr/lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/libdrm.so.2
 sudo -H ln -s /usr/lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/libdrm.so /usr/lib/aarch64-linux-gnu/libdrm.so.2
```

‌

3\. The error of  `'api.ignitionfuel.org'`

```
[Err] [REST.cc:205] Error in REST request

libcurl: (51) SSL: no alternative certificate subject name matches target host name 'api.ignitionfuel.org'
```

One has to edit ~/.ignition/fuel/config.yaml manually and change the line ‘https://api.ignitionfuel.org' to '[https://api.ignitionrobotics.org](https://api.ignitionrobotics.org)’ as to get it right. 

‌

best regards,

‌

airuchen

values.title: Adding joint in runtime through plugin -- physics incorrect

content.raw:
This is my first issue report, please tell me if something is missing. I’m using ROS Kinetic and Gazebo 7.16.

I’m trying to add a joint between 2 robots during runtime \(spawning the two robots separately and adding a new joint through a world plugin\).

After the joint is created, the physics become incorrect. I know that it is incorrect because my world is a zero gravity, and upon application of force/torque the robots don’t even move or stop shortly as if there was drag .

This bug can be visualized using the example in [https://github.com/pal-robotics/gazebo\_ros\_link\_attacher](https://github.com/pal-robotics/gazebo_ros_link_attacher), and setting the gravity in the world file to zero \(<gravity>0 0 0</gravity>\). As it is a zero gravity environment, when adding manually force to the gazebo models one would expect for it not to stop.
content.html:
This is my first issue report, please tell me if something is missing. I’m using ROS Kinetic and Gazebo 7.16.

I’m trying to add a joint between 2 robots during runtime (spawning the two robots separately and adding a new joint through a world plugin).

After the joint is created, the physics become incorrect. I know that it is incorrect because my world is a zero gravity, and upon application of force/torque the robots don’t even move or stop shortly as if there was drag .

This bug can be visualized using the example in https://github.com/pal-robotics/gazebo_ros_link_attacher, and setting the gravity in the world file to zero (<gravity>0 0 0</gravity>). As it is a zero gravity environment, when adding manually force to the gazebo models one would expect for it not to stop.

values.title: Which documentation tools does Gazebo use to generate documentation pages? (they are not listed anywhere)

content.raw:
Dear Gazebo Contributors and Users,

I really like the way Gazebo website with tutorials and docs is framed and would like to adopt the documentation software you use for Open Source projects in my institution.

If you do not mind, could you share the name of the software and theme you use to generate documentation pages like these?: [http://gazebosim.org/tutorials](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials) and [http://sdformat.org/spec](http://sdformat.org/spec)

I looked at _Sphinx_ \+ its various themes \+ _.rst_ files, but so far nothing found would resemble the layout of Gazebo online documentation.

Thank you for your time devoted to this matter and willingness to share.  
Kind regards,  
Jakub

values.title: Compilation fails with new DARTsim release

content.raw:
Recently, DARTsim has used C++14 features and as such compiling Gazebo fails due to `dart::make_unique` using `std::make_unique` (a c++14 feature)

As such, is there a plan to (choose one or more or a combination of)
* update the gazebo CMake version (to provide support for CXX_STANDARD per property)
* update the standard required for gazebosim
* stick with a preferred older version of dart
* supply `add_definition(-std=c++14)`

Also, compilation fails in gazebo/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTHeightmapShape.cc, lines 68 and 75
```
/usr/include/eigen3/Eigen/src/Core/AssignEvaluator.h:834:3: error: static assertion failed: YOU_MIXED_DIFFERENT_NUMERIC_TYPES__YOU_NEED_TO_USE_THE_CAST_METHOD_OF_MATRIXBASE_TO_CAST_NUMERIC_TYPES_EXPLICITLY
  834 |   EIGEN_CHECK_BINARY_COMPATIBILIY(Func,typename ActualDstTypeCleaned::Scalar,typename Src::Scalar);
      |   ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
make[2]: *** [gazebo/physics/CMakeFiles/gazebo_physics.dir/build.make:635: gazebo/physics/CMakeFiles/gazebo_physics.dir/dart/DARTHeightmapShape.cc.o] Error 1
```

The solution is to used `Eigen::Vector3f` instead of `Eigen::Vector3d`
content.html:
Recently, DARTsim has used C++14 features and as such compiling Gazebo fails due to dart::make_unique using std::make_unique (a c++14 feature)

As such, is there a plan to (choose one or more or a combination of) update the gazebo CMake version (to provide support for CXX_STANDARD per property) update the standard required for gazebosim stick with a preferred older version of dart supply add_definition(-std=c++14)

Also, compilation fails in gazebo/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTHeightmapShape.cc, lines 68 and 75

/usr/include/eigen3/Eigen/src/Core/AssignEvaluator.h:834:3: error: static assertion failed: YOU_MIXED_DIFFERENT_NUMERIC_TYPES__YOU_NEED_TO_USE_THE_CAST_METHOD_OF_MATRIXBASE_TO_CAST_NUMERIC_TYPES_EXPLICITLY
  834 |   EIGEN_CHECK_BINARY_COMPATIBILIY(Func,typename ActualDstTypeCleaned::Scalar,typename Src::Scalar);
      |   ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
make[2]: *** [gazebo/physics/CMakeFiles/gazebo_physics.dir/build.make:635: gazebo/physics/CMakeFiles/gazebo_physics.dir/dart/DARTHeightmapShape.cc.o] Error 1

The solution is to used Eigen::Vector3f instead of Eigen::Vector3d

values.title: TrackedVehiclePlugin: Angular Velocity Stored in Quaternion

content.raw: I am having issues utilizing the [TrackedVehiclePlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/WheelTrackedVehiclePlugin.cc). I created a plugin that allows me to use twist messages from a joystick in order to drive the robot. When I created my plugin I modeled it after the [KeysToCmdVelPlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/KeysToCmdVelPlugin.cc) with how the publisher works. It works for the most part especially when only linear velocity is applied. The part I am having problems with is when I apply angular velocity. If I set the maximum allowable angular velocity to be greater than pi, and I command the robot to go that speed then the angular velocity will start to wrap around \(-3.14 to 3.14\) and the robot starts to turn the opposite direction. This happens for every multiple of pi \(<2_pi flips directions once, <3_pi flips directions twice, ...\).  I think this issue is similar to [#2839](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2389), because the TrackedVehiclePlugin is subscribing to a pose message which stores the angular velocity in a quaternion.
content.html: I am having issues utilizing the TrackedVehiclePlugin. I created a plugin that allows me to use twist messages from a joystick in order to drive the robot. When I created my plugin I modeled it after the KeysToCmdVelPlugin with how the publisher works. It works for the most part especially when only linear velocity is applied. The part I am having problems with is when I apply angular velocity. If I set the maximum allowable angular velocity to be greater than pi, and I command the robot to go that speed then the angular velocity will start to wrap around (-3.14 to 3.14) and the robot starts to turn the opposite direction. This happens for every multiple of pi (<2_pi flips directions once, <3_pi flips directions twice, ...). I think this issue is similar to #2839, because the TrackedVehiclePlugin is subscribing to a pose message which stores the angular velocity in a quaternion.

values.title: deadlock on World::OnRequest and TopicManager::AddNode

content.raw:
deadlock can happen when loading actors during gazebo startup, receiveMutex and nodeMutex are locked by multiple threads at  the same time, causing a deadlock. It happens while thread 60 is processing factory messages and thread 5 is processing nodes.

I can think of 2 ways to fix it:

1. copy `dataPtr->factoryMsgs` to a temp container in `World::ProcessFactoryMsgs` so we don't have to hold on to `receiveMutex` lock.
2. introduce a new mutex to protect `factoryMsgs`, so it doesn't share the same `receiveMutex` lock with many other containers.

Not sure which solution is more preferred, or if there is a better solution.

```
(gdb) thread 5
[Switching to thread 5 (Thread 0x7f2a03fff700 (LWP 7070))]
#0  __lll_lock_wait () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/lowlevellock.S:135
135     in ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/lowlevellock.S
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007f2a4281410d in __lll_lock_wait () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/lowlevellock.S:135
#1  0x00007f2a4280d098 in __GI___pthread_mutex_lock (mutex=0x5600f281b348) at ../nptl/pthread_mutex_lock.c:113
#2  0x00007f2a4492a97d in __gthread_mutex_lock(__gthread_mutex_t*) (__mutex=0x5600f281b348) at /usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/c++/7/bits/gthr-default.h:748
#3  0x00007f2a4492a9cd in __gthread_recursive_mutex_lock(__gthread_recursive_mutex_t*) (__mutex=0x5600f281b348) at /usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/c++/7/bits/gthr-default.h:810
#4  0x00007f2a4492f10c in std::recursive_mutex::lock() (this=0x5600f281b348) at /usr/include/c++/7/mutex:107
#5  0x00007f2a44931c42 in std::lock_guard<std::recursive_mutex>::lock_guard(std::recursive_mutex&) (this=0x7f2a03ffd720, __m=...) at /usr/include/c++/7/bits/std_mutex.h:162

receiveMutex already locked at another thread std::lock_guard<std::recursive_mutex> lock(this->dataPtr->receiveMutex);
#6  0x00007f2a422d3b96 in gazebo::physics::World::OnRequest(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&) (this=0x5600f282b570, _msg=...) at /home/teokp/source/gazebo/gazebo/gazebo/physics/World.cc:1500

#7  0x00007f2a4230409f in boost::_mfi::mf1<void, gazebo::physics::World, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>::operator()(gazebo::physics::World*, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&) const (this=0x5600f61fce48, p=0x5600f282b570, a1=...) at /usr/include/boost/bind/mem_fn_template.hpp:165
#8  0x00007f2a42302fe0 in boost::_bi::list2<boost::_bi::value<gazebo::physics::World*>, boost::arg<1> >::operator()<boost::_mfi::mf1<void, gazebo::physics::World, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>, boost::_bi::rrlist1<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&> >(boost::_bi::type<void>, boost::_mfi::mf1<void, gazebo::physics::World, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>&, boost::_bi::rrlist1<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>&, int) (this=0x5600f61fce58, f=..., a=...) at /usr/include/boost/bind/bind.hpp:319
#9  0x00007f2a423016af in boost::_bi::bind_t<void, boost::_mfi::mf1<void, gazebo::physics::World, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>, boost::_bi::list2<boost::_bi::value<gazebo::physics::World*>, boost::arg<1> > >::operator()<boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&) (this=0x5600f61fce48, a1=...) at /usr/include/boost/bind/bind.hpp:1306
#10 0x00007f2a422ff33f in boost::detail::function::void_function_obj_invoker1<boost::_bi::bind_t<void, boost::_mfi::mf1<void, gazebo::physics::World, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>, boost::_bi::list2<boost::_bi::value<gazebo::physics::World*>, boost::arg<1> > >, void, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>::invoke(boost::detail::function::function_buffer&, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&) (function_obj_ptr=..., a0=...) at /usr/include/boost/function/function_template.hpp:159
#11 0x00007f2a421a60cc in boost::function1<void, boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&>::operator()(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::Request const> const&) const (this=0x5600f61fce40, a0=...) at /usr/include/boost/function/function_template.hpp:759

    at /home/teokp/source/gazebo/gazebo/gazebo/transport/CallbackHelper.hh:149

nodeMutex is locked here boost::recursive_mutex::scoped_lock lock(this->nodeMutex);
